title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement dmorrison01@ucla.edu. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

code: @Manual{,   title = {rwicc: Regression with Interval-Censored Covariates},   author = {Douglas Morrison and Ron Brookmeyer},   year = {2022},   note = {https://d-morrison.github.io/rwicc/, https://github.com/d-morrison/rwicc}, }

title: Regression with Interval-Censored Covariates
text: rwicc (“Regression Interval-Censored Covariates”) R software package implementing analysis regression model involving interval-censored covariate, described “Regression Interval-Censored Covariates: Application Cross-Sectional Incidence Estimation” Morrison, Laeyendecker, Brookmeyer (Biometrics, 2021): https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/biom.13472. analysis uses joint model distributions outcome interest interval-censored covariate, treated latent variable; model parameters estimated maximum likelihood using EM algorithm. submodel used distribution interval-censored covariate somewhat specific application interest (estimation mean duration biomarker-defined window period cross-sectional incidence estimation), package may immediately applicable problems. publishing goal making results paper easier reproduce hope others might adapt pieces code applications. Please feel free contact us questions code paper!

title: Regression with Interval-Censored Covariates
text: can install development version GitHub :

title: Regression with Interval-Censored Covariates
text: See: https://d-morrison.github.io/rwicc/articles/--use-rwicc.html

title: Regression with Interval-Censored Covariates

what: Fit a logistic regression model with an interval-censored covariate — fit_joint_model
title: Fit a logistic regression model with an interval-censored covariate — fit_joint_model
text: function fits logistic regression model binary outcome Y interval-censored covariate T, using EM algorithm, described Morrison et al (2021); doi: 10.1111/biom.13472 .

title: Fit a logistic regression model with an interval-censored covariate — fit_joint_model
code: fit_joint_model(   participant_level_data,   obs_level_data,   model_formula = stats::formula(Y ~ T),   mu_function = compute_mu,   bin_width = 1,   denom_offset = 0.1,   EM_toler_loglik = 0.1,   EM_toler_est = 1e-04,   EM_max_iterations = Inf,   glm_tolerance = 1e-07,   glm_maxit = 20,   initial_S_estimate_location = 0.25,   coef_change_metric = "max abs rel diff coefs",   verbose = FALSE )

title: Fit a logistic regression model with an interval-censored covariate — fit_joint_model
text: participant_level_data data.frame tibble following variables: ID: participant ID E: study enrollment date L: date last negative test seroconversion R: date first positive test seroconversion Cohort` (optional): variable can used stratify modeling seroconversion distribution. obs_level_data data.frame tibble following variables: ID: participant ID O: biomarker sample collection dates Y: MAA classifications (binary outcomes) model_formula functional form regression model p(y|t) (formula() object) mu_function function taking vector regression coefficient estimates input outputting estimate mu (mean duration MAA-positive infection). bin_width number days possible seroconversion dates (integer) denom_offset offset value added denominator hazard estimates improve numerical stability EM_toler_loglik convergence cutoff log-likelihood criterion ("Delta_L" paper) EM_toler_est convergence cutoff parameter estimate criterion ("Delta_theta" paper) EM_max_iterations number EM iterations perform giving still converged. glm_tolerance convergence cutoff glm fit M step glm_maxit iterations cutoff glm fit M step initial_S_estimate_location determines seroconversion date guessed initialize algorithm; can decimal 0 1; 0.5 = midpoint imputation, 0.25 = 1st quartile, 0 = last negative, etc. coef_change_metric string indicating type parameter estimate criterion use: "max abs rel diff coefs" "Delta_theta" criterion described paper. "max abs diff coefs" maximum absolute change coefficients (divided old values); criterion can useful parameters close 0. "diff mu" absolute change mu, may helpful incidence estimate calibration setting elsewhere. verbose whether print algorithm progress details console

title: Fit a logistic regression model with an interval-censored covariate — fit_joint_model
text: list following elements: Theta: estimated regression coefficients model p(Y|T) Mu: estimated mean window period (transformation Theta) Omega: table estimated parameters model p(S|E). converged: indicator whether algorithm reached cutoff criteria reaching specified maximum iterations. 1 = reached cutoffs, 0 = . iterations: number EM iterations completed algorithm stopped. convergence_metrics: four convergence metrics

title: Fit a logistic regression model with an interval-censored covariate — fit_joint_model
text: Morrison, Laeyendecker, Brookmeyer (2021). "Regression interval-censored covariates: Application cross-sectional incidence estimation". Biometrics. doi: 10.1111/biom.13472 .

title: Fit a logistic regression model with an interval-censored covariate — fit_joint_model
code: if (FALSE) {  # simulate data: study_data <- simulate_interval_censoring()  # fit model: EM_algorithm_outputs <- fit_joint_model(   obs_level_data = study_data$obs_data,   participant_level_data = study_data$pt_data ) }

text: participant_level_data data.frame tibble following variables: ID: participant ID E: study enrollment date L: date last negative test seroconversion R: date first positive test seroconversion Cohort` (optional): variable can used stratify modeling seroconversion distribution. obs_level_data data.frame tibble following variables: ID: participant ID O: biomarker sample collection dates Y: MAA classifications (binary outcomes) maxit maximum iterations, passed bigglm tolerance convergence criterion, passed bigglm

title: Fit model using midpoint imputation — fit_midpoint_model
text: vector logistic regression coefficient estimates

title: Fit model using midpoint imputation — fit_midpoint_model
code: sim_data = simulate_interval_censoring(   "theta" = c(0.986, -3.88),   "study_cohort_size" = 4500,   "preconversion_interval_length" = 365,   "hazard_alpha" = 1,   "hazard_beta" = 0.5)  theta_est_midpoint = fit_midpoint_model(   obs_level_data = sim_data$obs_data,   participant_level_data = sim_data$pt_data )

title: Fit model using uniform imputation — fit_uniform_model
code: fit_uniform_model(   participant_level_data,   obs_level_data,   maxit = 1000,   tolerance = 1e-08,   n_imputations = 10 )

title: Fit model using uniform imputation — fit_uniform_model
text: participant_level_data data.frame tibble following variables: ID: participant ID E: study enrollment date L: date last negative test seroconversion R: date first positive test seroconversion Cohort` (optional): variable can used stratify modeling seroconversion distribution. obs_level_data data.frame tibble following variables: ID: participant ID O: biomarker sample collection dates Y: MAA classifications (binary outcomes) maxit maximum iterations, passed bigglm tolerance convergence criterion, passed bigglm n_imputations number imputed data sets create

text: vector logistic regression coefficient estimates

title: Fit model using uniform imputation — fit_uniform_model
code: sim_data = simulate_interval_censoring(   "theta" = c(0.986, -3.88),   "study_cohort_size" = 4500,   "preconversion_interval_length" = 365,   "hazard_alpha" = 1,   "hazard_beta" = 0.5)  theta_est_midpoint = fit_uniform_model(   obs_level_data = sim_data$obs_data,   participant_level_data = sim_data$pt_data )

what: plot estimated and true CDFs for seroconversion date distribution — plot_CDF
title: plot estimated and true CDFs for seroconversion date distribution — plot_CDF
text: plot estimated true CDFs seroconversion date distribution

title: plot estimated and true CDFs for seroconversion date distribution — plot_CDF
plot estimated and true CDFs for seroconversion date distribution — plot_CDF
text: true_hazard_alpha data-generating hazard start study true_hazard_beta change data-generating hazard per calendar year omega.hat tibble estimated discrete hazards

title: plot estimated and true CDFs for seroconversion date distribution — plot_CDF
text: ggplot

title: plot estimated and true CDFs for seroconversion date distribution — plot_CDF
code: if (FALSE) {  hazard_alpha = 1 hazard_beta = 0.5 study_data <- simulate_interval_censoring(   "hazard_alpha" = hazard_alpha,   "hazard_beta" = hazard_beta)  # fit model: EM_algorithm_outputs <- fit_joint_model(   obs_level_data = study_data$obs_data,   participant_level_data = study_data$pt_data ) plot1 = plot_CDF(   true_hazard_alpha = hazard_alpha,   true_hazard_beta = hazard_beta,   omega.hat = EM_algorithm_outputs$Omega)  print(plot1) }

what: Plot true and estimated curves for P(Y=1|T=t) — plot_phi_curves
title: Plot true and estimated curves for P(Y=1|T=t) — plot_phi_curves
text: Plot true estimated curves P(Y=1|T=t)

title: Plot true and estimated curves for P(Y=1|T=t) — plot_phi_curves
Plot true and estimated curves for P(Y=1|T=t) — plot_phi_curves
text: theta_true coefficients data-generating model P(Y=1|T=t) theta.hat_joint estimated coefficients joint model theta.hat_midpoint estimated coefficients midpoint imputation theta.hat_uniform estimated coefficients uniform imputation

title: Plot true and estimated curves for P(Y=1|T=t) — plot_phi_curves
text: ggplot

title: Plot true and estimated curves for P(Y=1|T=t) — plot_phi_curves
code: if (FALSE) {  theta_true = c(0.986, -3.88) hazard_alpha = 1 hazard_beta = 0.5 sim_data = simulate_interval_censoring(   "theta" = theta_true,   "study_cohort_size" = 4500,   "preconversion_interval_length" = 365,   "hazard_alpha" = hazard_alpha,   "hazard_beta" = hazard_beta)  # extract the participant-level and observation-level simulated data: sim_participant_data = sim_data$pt_data sim_obs_data = sim_data$obs_data rm(sim_data)  # joint model: EM_algorithm_outputs = fit_joint_model(   obs_level_data = sim_obs_data,   participant_level_data = sim_participant_data,   bin_width = 7,   verbose = FALSE)  # midpoint imputation: theta_est_midpoint = fit_midpoint_model(   obs_level_data = sim_obs_data,   participant_level_data = sim_participant_data )  # uniform imputation: theta_est_uniform = fit_uniform_model(   obs_level_data = sim_obs_data,   participant_level_data = sim_participant_data ) plot2 = plot_phi_curves(   theta_true = theta_true,   theta.hat_uniform = theta_est_uniform,   theta.hat_midpoint = theta_est_midpoint,   theta.hat_joint = EM_algorithm_outputs$Theta)  print(plot2) }

what: rwicc: Regression with Interval-Censored Covariates — rwicc
title: rwicc: Regression with Interval-Censored Covariates — rwicc
text: rwicc package implements regression model interval-censored covariate using EM algorithm, described Morrison et al (2021); doi: 10.1111/biom.13472 .

title: rwicc: Regression with Interval-Censored Covariates — rwicc
text: main rwicc functions : simulate_interval_censoring fit_joint_model

title: rwicc: Regression with Interval-Censored Covariates — rwicc
text: Morrison, Laeyendecker, Brookmeyer (2021). "Regression interval-censored covariates: Application cross-sectional incidence estimation". Biometrics. doi: 10.1111/biom.13472 .

what: Inverse survival function for time-to-event variable with linear hazard function — seroconversion_inverse_survival_function
title: Inverse survival function for time-to-event variable with linear hazard function — seroconversion_inverse_survival_function
text: function determines seroconversion date corresponding provided probability survival. See doi: 10.1111/biom.13472 , Supporting Information, Section .4.

title: Inverse survival function for time-to-event variable with linear hazard function — seroconversion_inverse_survival_function
Inverse survival function for time-to-event variable with linear hazard function — seroconversion_inverse_survival_function
text: u vector seroconversion survival probabilities e vector time differences study start enrollment (years) hazard_alpha instantaneous hazard seroconversion study start date hazard_beta change hazard per year study start date

title: Inverse survival function for time-to-event variable with linear hazard function — seroconversion_inverse_survival_function
text: numeric vector time differences study start seroconversion (years)

title: Inverse survival function for time-to-event variable with linear hazard function — seroconversion_inverse_survival_function
text: Morrison, Laeyendecker, Brookmeyer (2021). "Regression interval-censored covariates: Application cross-sectional incidence estimation". Biometrics, doi: 10.1111/biom.13472 .

what: Simulate a dataset with interval-censored seroconversion dates — simulate_interval_censoring
title: Simulate a dataset with interval-censored seroconversion dates — simulate_interval_censoring
text: simulate_interval_censoring generates simulated data set data-generating model based typical structure cohort study HIV biomarker progression, described Morrison et al (2021); doi: 10.1111/biom.13472 .

title: Simulate a dataset with interval-censored seroconversion dates — simulate_interval_censoring
code: simulate_interval_censoring(   study_cohort_size = 4500,   hazard_alpha = 1,   hazard_beta = 0.5,   preconversion_interval_length = 84,   theta = c(0.986, -3.88),   probability_of_ever_seroconverting = 0.05,   years_in_study = 10,   max_scheduling_offset = 7,   days_from_study_start_to_recruitment_end = 365,   study_start_date = lubridate::ymd("2001-01-01") )

title: Simulate a dataset with interval-censored seroconversion dates — simulate_interval_censoring
text: study_cohort_size number participants simulate (N_0 paper) hazard_alpha hazard (instantaneous risk) seroconversion start date cohort study participants risk seroconversion hazard_beta change hazard per calendar year preconversion_interval_length number days tests seroconversion theta parameters logistic model (linear functional ) specifying probability MAA-positive biomarkers function time since seroconversion probability_of_ever_seroconverting probability participant risk HIV seroconversion years_in_study duration follow-participant max_scheduling_offset maximum divergence pre-seroconversion followup visits prescribed schedule days_from_study_start_to_recruitment_end length recruitment period study_start_date date study starts recruitment ("d_0" main text). value parameter affect simulation results; necessary reference point generating E, L, R, O, S.

title: Simulate a dataset with interval-censored seroconversion dates — simulate_interval_censoring
text: list containing following two tibbles: pt_data: tibble participant-level information, following columns: ID: participant ID E: enrollment date L: date last HIV test prior seroconversion R: date first HIV test seroconversion obs_data: tibble longitudinal observations following columns: ID: participant ID O: dates biomarker sample collection Y: MAA classifications biomarker samples

title: Simulate a dataset with interval-censored seroconversion dates — simulate_interval_censoring
text: Morrison, Laeyendecker, Brookmeyer (2021). "Regression interval-censored covariates: Application cross-sectional incidence estimation". Biometrics. doi: 10.1111/biom.13472 .

title: Simulate a dataset with interval-censored seroconversion dates — simulate_interval_censoring
code: study_data <- simulate_interval_censoring() participant_characteristics <- study_data$pt_data longitudinal_observations <- study_data$obs_data
